introduction.para: In this article we will present the conceptual help introduced in the October 2007 CTP release of the Sandcastle Help Compiler System.

Previous release of the Sandcastle provided support for building API references for source codes based on the .NET XML-Doc format. While this may be useful in most cases, a complete software documentation will include two parts; the API reference documentation and the "User Manual".

While some software provide the manual in the Microsoft Word or Adobe PDF formats, most of us prefer the HTML format. In the HTML format, we prefer a look and feel similar to the API reference documentation.
Many companies are now providing only the online help systems; not only is this convenience, more useful and cost saving, but it also makes our Al Gore happy!

alert.para: Al Gore might refuse to be renamed Al Green, because writing that might take more paper space, more energy to spell out, and more ink and coal to print!

introduction.para: Now, with the release of the October 2007 CTP, even the poorest ISV can produce a professional documentations at a price he/she can afford - free.

Well, "free" itself is a price and in this case very expensive one. The conceptual help support in the Sandcastle came without a documentation (the documenter is not documented), making it difficult for the current Sandcastle GUI providers to integrate it into their tools.
This article, therefore, aims to provide the following:

listItem.para: Reduce the "free" cost of learning to use the conceptual help so that many can explore the potentials of this useful tool.
Provide information to help integrating the conceptual help support in new and existing tools.

introduction.para: Basically, I am trying to share with you all I have, currently, in my attempt to learn and master the conceptual help support in Sandcastle. I will be releasing a series of articles on this, but have provided all the tools and facilities in the accompanying download files, so that you will not have to work at my pace.
In this article, I will present the Quick Start to both introduce you and get you started. It will also help me gather information for the next article.
Now, for those new to Sandcastle's conceptual help, let me give a "free" screen-shot of a typically output, which is actually part of the download files.

content.para: Conceptual means pertaining to concepts or to the forming of concepts, so a conceptual help is a documentation of the concepts or how your software program will help to realize some concepts or ideas. Well, that is me trying to be technical, and believe me it is not accurate. The accurate version follows...

The conceptual help is based on the Microsoft Assistance Markup Language or MAML, an XML-based markup language developed by the Microsoft User Assistance Platform team to provide user assistance for the Windows Vista. The ideal behind the MAML is similar to DocBook (I do not know which is better).

The MAML consists of several distinct content types, each one specific to a type of document. The MAML content types include: conceptual, glossary, procedural or how-to, reference, troubleshooting, etc.
The term "conceptual help" is actually a out of place since the "conceptual content" is a just one of the content types defined by the MAML.

The MAML specification is currently not available, but the Sandcastle Team provided the schema of a derived version for developers. The schema is currently incomplete, which is adding to the "free" cost I mentioned earlier.

listItem.para: The <title> tag is actually required for a successful compilation of the help, even thought not included in the schema.
The <topic>'s id must be a GUID, uniquely identifying each document in the help system.
The file containing each document must be named with the <topic>'s id value.

content.para: Finally the good news: the Sandcastle Team provided the tool to transform, with varying degree of completion and accuracy, the various content types to both HtmlHelp 1.x and 2.x for the presentation styles supported. A typical output using the VS-2005 presentation style, which is the best supported style, is shown above.

listItem.para: This is an easy to use library that will help you concentrate on the content types instead of how to build your help files.
It will create the copies of your files with the the GUID names extracted from the topic id in the directory required by the Sandcastle configuration file.
It will create various files including the table of content.
It will help you compile your file and log the output.
Even the MAML is well documentated, the version included in the October 2007 CTP version of the Sandcastle is not complete, making it difficult to extract the documentation.
I have managed to extract a documentation of the provided schema, not very nice but useful.
It is named Maml.chm and located in the Builder folder.
The sample sources, in C# and VB.NET, of the tutorial presented below.

It is an illustrative example that shows you what you can do with the Sandcastle, and if you take a look at the source to see how it was done.
It aims to be a guide, a tutorial and a cookbook!
